DataElement.preferredName: Testicular Cancer International Germ Cell Consensus Classification Prognosis Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents the prognostic stage according to factors from the International Germ Cell Cancer Collaborative Group (IGCCCG).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Malignant Testicular Germ Cell Tumor International Germ Cell Consensus Classification Prognosis
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor predominantly affecting young men and often associated with cryptorchidism.  Seminoma is the most frequently seen malignant testicular germ cell tumor, followed by embryonal carcinoma and yolk sac tumor. -- 2004_A laboratory test result identifying markers in a blood sample.  It is used in combination with other measures to determine testicular cancer staging._A staging system for metastatic malignant germ cell tumors developed by the International Germ Cell Cancer Collaborative Group.  It is a factor-based system that produced three prognostic groups; good prognosis, intermediate prognosis, and poor prognosis._Prediction of the probable course and outcome of a disease.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor predominantly affecting young men and often associated with cryptorchidism.  Seminoma is the most frequently seen malignant testicular germ cell tumor, followed by embryonal carcinoma and yolk sac tumor. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A malignant germ cell tumor that arises from the testis. It predominantly affects young men. Seminoma is the most frequently seen malignant testicular germ cell tumor, followed by embryonal carcinoma and yolk sac tumor.

Property.preferredName: International Germ Cell Consensus Classification Prognosis
Property.preferredDefinition: A staging system for metastatic malignant germ cell tumors developed by the International Germ Cell Cancer Collaborative Group.  It is a factor-based system that produced three prognostic groups; good prognosis, intermediate prognosis, and poor prognosis.:Prediction of the probable course and outcome of a disease.

Concepts.longName: International Germ Cell Consensus Risk Classification
Concepts.definition: A risk classification system for malignant germ cell tumors developed by the International Germ Cell Cancer Collaborative Group.
Prediction of the probable course and outcome of a disease.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for Testicular Enrollment form per request by T.Lichtenberg. mc 9/13/13

ValueDomain.preferredName: International Germ Cell Consensus Classification Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A staging system for metastatic malignant germ cell tumors developed by the International Germ Cell Cancer Collaborative Group.  It is a factor-based system that produced three prognostic groups; good prognosis, intermediate prognosis, and poor prognosis._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of low value or worth.: Prediction of the probable course and outcome of a disease.

Concepts.definition: Prediction of the probable course and outcome of a disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lying between two extremes in time or space or degree.: Prediction of the probable course and outcome of a disease.

Prediction of the probable course and outcome of a disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A staging system for metastatic malignant germ cell tumors developed by the International Germ Cell Cancer Collaborative Group.  It is a factor-based system that produced three prognostic groups; good prognosis, intermediate prognosis, and poor prognosis.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A risk classification system for malignant germ cell tumors developed by the International Germ Cell Cancer Collaborative Group.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
